Name: Ambonese Malay
Language_status_ethnologue: 3 (Wider communication). Became an LWC through trade, and is used in inter-cultural communication, market, and some media.

Name: North Moluccan Malay
Language_status_ethnologue: 3 (Wider communication). Became LWC through trade, also used in daily life, inter-ethnic contact.

Name: Papuan Malay
Language_status_ethnologue: 3 (Wider communication). LWC in the coastal areas of West Papua. Became an LWC mostly as a result of Dutch colonial language policies in the early 20th century, and before that, to a rather limited extent, through trade (Kluge 2014:11–15).

Name: Manado Malay
Language_status_ethnologue: 3 (Wider communication). An important, growing lingua franca in many parts of Sulawesi.

Name: Sudanese Creole Arabic
Language_status_ethnologue: 3 (Wider communication). Used as L1 or L2 in Juba and other towns in Equatoria. As a creole and lingua franca, this language varies enormously in form from place to place, and from speaker to speaker (depending on subject matter and interlocuter), and is changing rapidly.

Name: Afro-Seminole Creole
Classification_ethnologue: Creole, English based, Atlantic, Eastern, Northern

Name: Bahamas Creole English
Classification_ethnologue: Creole, English based, Atlantic, Eastern, Northern
Language_status_ethnologue: 6a (Vigorous). De facto language of national identity.

Name: Sea Island Creole English
Classification_ethnologue: Creole, English based, Atlantic, Eastern, Northern

Name: Antigua and Barbuda Creole English
Classification_ethnologue: Creole, English based, Atlantic, Eastern, Southern
Language_status_ethnologue: 6a (Vigorous). De facto language of national identity.

Name: Bajan
Classification_ethnologue: Creole, English based, Atlantic, Eastern, Southern
Language_status_ethnologue: 6a (Vigorous). De facto language of national identity.

Name: Grenadian Creole English
Classification_ethnologue: Creole, English based, Atlantic, Eastern, Southern
Language_status_ethnologue: 6a (Vigorous). De facto language of national identity.

Name: Guyanese Creole English
Classification_ethnologue: Creole, English based, Atlantic, Eastern, Southern
Language_status_ethnologue: 5 (Developing). De facto language of national identity.

Name: Vincentian Creole English
Classification_ethnologue: Creole, English based, Atlantic, Eastern, Southern
Language_status_ethnologue: 6a (Vigorous). De facto language of national identity.

Name: Tobagonian Creole English
Classification_ethnologue: Creole, English based, Atlantic, Eastern, Southern
Language_status_ethnologue: 6a (Vigorous). De facto language of provincial identity in Tobago.

Name: Trinidadian Creole English
Classification_ethnologue: Creole, English based, Atlantic, Eastern, Southern
Language_status_ethnologue: 6a (Vigorous). De facto language of national identity.

Name: Virgin Islands Creole English
Classification_ethnologue: Creole, English based, Atlantic, Eastern, Southern
Language_status_ethnologue: 6a (Vigorous). De facto language of national identity.

Name: Turks And Caicos Creole English
Language_status_ethnologue: 6b (Threatened). De facto language of national identity.

Name: Pichi
Language_status_ethnologue: 3 (Wider communication). Used as LWC across Bioko island, including the capital city of Malabo, in all domains except education and government.

Name: Cameroon Pidgin
Language_status_ethnologue: 3 (Wider communication). Since 1884 used by police, prisons, urban school children at play. Now the most widespread lingua franca in Cameroon, used by about half the population (Todd and Mühlhäusler 1978).

Name: Aukan
Classification_ethnologue: Creole, English based, Atlantic, Suriname, Ndyuka

Name: Kwinti
Classification_ethnologue: Creole, English based, Atlantic, Suriname, Ndyuka

Name: Sranan Tongo
Language_status_ethnologue: 3 (Wider communication). De facto national working language. Lingua franca of 80% of the country, including the Hindustanis, Javanese, Chinese, American Indians, and Bush Negroes.

Name: Belize Kriol English
Language_status_ethnologue: 3 (Wider communication). Lingua franca in much of the country.

Name: Nicaragua Creole English
Language_status_ethnologue: 3 (Wider communication). Statutory language of provincial identity in northern and southern areas (1993, Atlantic Coast Languages Act No. 162, Article 4).

Name: Jamaican Creole English
Language_status_ethnologue: 5 (Developing). De facto language of national identity.

Name: Pitcairn-Norfolk
Language_status_ethnologue: 6a (Vigorous). Statutory language of national identity (2004, Norfolk Island Language (Norf’k) Act No. 25, Section 4), restrictions in Sec. 5 of Act No. 25 of 2004 bar meaningful official use.

Name: Bislama
Language_status_ethnologue: 1 (National). Statutory national language (1980, Constitution, Art 3(1)). Most in the country understand and use it as lingua franca and as a symbol of national identity.

Name: Saint Lucian Creole French
Language_status_ethnologue: 5 (Developing). De facto language of national identity.

Name: Guadeloupean Creole French
Language_status_ethnologue: 6a (Vigorous). De facto language of national identity.

Name: Morisyen
Language_status_ethnologue: 5 (Developing). De facto language of national identity.

Name: Kituba (Democratic Republic of Congo)
Language_status_ethnologue: 2 (Provincial). Statutory provincial language in Bas-Congo, Bandundu regions (2006, Constitution, Article 1(8)).

Name: Kituba (Congo)
Language_status_ethnologue: 3 (Wider communication). Statutory language of national identity (2002, Constitution, Article 6), recognized as lingua franca. Kituba is used throughout the south in churches, the market and the media (2014 SIL).

Name: Sãotomense
Language_status_ethnologue: 6b (Threatened). De facto language of provincial identity in São Tomé Island except south tip.

Name: Kabuverdianu
Language_status_ethnologue: 4 (Educational). Statutory language of national identity (1992, Constitution, Article 9(2)), not co-equal with Portuguese.

Name: Upper Guinea Crioulo
Language_status_ethnologue: 5 (Developing). De facto language of national identity.

Name: Broome Pearling Lugger Pidgin
Language_status_ethnologue: 9 (Second language only). Lingua franca on pearling boats between Malays, Japanese, Chinese, and Aborigines.

Name: Hiri Motu
Language_status_ethnologue: 3 (Wider communication). Recognized language (1975, Constitution, Articles 67 and 68). Used long before European contact by participants in the Hiri trade cycle between the Motu people and their neighbors on the south east coast of the island of New Guinea. Since about 1970 the use of Hiri Motu as a lingua franca has been declining in favor of English [eng] and Tok Pisin [tpi]; speakers are mostly older adults and concentrated in Central Province and Gulf Province.
